qas.question: What is an aerodome with facilities for flights to take off and land?
What is an aerially accessible open space that includes at least one active surface such as a runway or a helipad?

answers.text: aerodrome with facilities for flights to take off and land

plausible_answers.text: an aerodrome with facilities for flights to take off and land

qas.question: What is the definition of a control tower?

plausible_answers.text: fixed base operator services, airport aprons, air traffic control centres, passenger facilities such as restaurants and lounges, and emergency services.

qas.question: What do larger control towers have?
What is an example of the area around a utility building?

plausible_answers.text: one operationally active surface such as a runway

qas.question: What is an example of an airport apron?

plausible_answers.text: an aerodrome with facilities for flights to take off and land

qas.question: What is the definition of a helipad?

context: An <a0_0>airport<a0_0/> is <b3_0><b7_0>an <a2_0>aerodrome with facilities for flights to take off and land<b7_0/><b3_0/><a2_0/>. Airports often have facilities to store and maintain aircraft, and a control tower. An airport consists of <b5_0>a <a1_0>landing area<b5_0/><a1_0/>, which comprises an aerially accessible open space including at least <b6_0>one operationally active surface such as a runway<b6_0/> for a plane to take off or a helipad, and often includes adjacent utility buildings such as control towers, hangars  and terminals. Larger airports may have <b4_0>fixed base operator services, airport aprons, air traffic control centres, passenger facilities such as restaurants and lounges, and emergency services.
